replies.body: Fervor of Battle is much better than Grasp of the undying on Fizz and Ekko, sure Grasp of the Undying is good for laning phase but the added damage from Fervor is better and scales much better with levels. Another point is the health percentage steal is fairly useless in terms of sustain in lane as there may tend to be lane swaps and most top laners in the meta already have some innate sustain. Overall Fervor on the top laner carries Ekko and Fizz are much more useful through the abuse of their invulnerable abilities; Ekko ult and Fizz Troll pole which does prolong skirmish and fights AS they put out overall more consistent damage through the use of fervor.

Here's my theory on the keystone preference:
Both Fizz and Ekko, along with Maokai as top laners have similar item build paths due to their similarities in damage sources (with abilities that deal mostly magic damage) and also fill the same role in team fights, that of being a tank.  So as all three champions have similar item builds, roles and even rune pages the reason for the differing keystones is within the differences within the different kits that the champions have. The main differences in performing as a tank that exist between these three champions is the reliability and consistency in being able to lock down targets with cc effects, the way in which they mitigate damage they take and the way that the utilise their auto attacks. Fizz only has the 1 second knock up from his shark for cc and a small reduction in basic attack damage from his passive in terms of damage mitigation, Ekko has the delayed stun from his w for cc and for damage mitigation he has the shield from the w and healing of his ult, while Maokai has consistent healing due to his passive and 20% damage reduction from his ult with more consistent and reliable cc in the form of his q knock up and his targeted root. In terms of auto attack usage, Fizz has his w passive and active linked to auto attack usage, which provide execute damage plus his q which applies on-hit effects. Ekko has execute damage on autos to targets below 30% health and an on-hit effect applier in his e. Maokai only has his passive which utilises his auto attacks to heal him. This then explains the reasoning behind the tendency to take fervor of battle over grasp of the undying on Fizz and Ekko as the increased damage that it provides gets further increased due to their ability to generate extra auto attacks and their execute damage as the increased damage is more valuable to them than sustain due to their lower consistency in mitigating damage through cc or other means, in particular for Fizz who often will take 18/12/0 in order to make use of dangerous game for sustain which further benefits him for taking fervor over grasp as the healing from dangerous game will be more beneficial to Fizz when low than the healing from grasp, and fervor will allow Fizz to make use of dangerous game more sooner and more frequently. For Maokai on the other hand, grasp adds another source of consistent healing which can often buy him enough time to get another usage of his passive, which increases his ability to mitigate damage by more than just the healing from grasp. In summary, fervor allows Fizz and Ekko to get kills faster which helps mitigate damage for their team as the damage output they stop from opponents due to killing them faster is more damage stopped then the amount they would be able to block by healing from grasp, whereas Maokai is able to mitigate more damage through healing than increased damage output.

A lot of it has to do with the build paths to both keystone masteries. In my opinion, the bonuses to damage output from the fervor build path outweigh what bonuses you get from the grasp build path.

Fizz and Ekko primarily do magic damage and are very mobile? By using Fervor of Battle, you're able to diversify your damage (which is usually sustained for both these champs seeing as they're pretty tanky). This means that you can still do a lot of damage to the squishies even if they do build a defensive item (like how you'd see adc go mercurial [Magic Resist] and mages go Zhonyas or Abyssal). 

Also, the amount of damage Fervor does once it's stacked up (which is easy to do on Ekko and Fizz because they incorporate autos as well as spells when fighting) is vastly superior to grasp of the undying at almost all stages of the game [In a late game scenario with level 18, full build: 2.5% of ~3.5k hp is only 87.5 magic damage every FOUR seconds whilst fervor will be doing a bonus 111.92 damage PER auto, since we've already established that it's very easy to stack fervor quickly] (especially when you go iceborn since it doesn't give hp, so you're losing more scaling on your grasp procs). 

Also, I reckon Fervor is pretty good into tanks since they'd have to use more gold to build resistances against AD and AP damage coming from Fizz/ Ekko. When your fervor is fully stacked you'll be doing a lot more damage to squishies as well as tanks especially compared to when you were running grasp!

simple analysis of this is in the raw numbers, example of this is around 20 min in a game most top laners are around lvl 12-13. @ 8 stacks you will do an extra 84.64 physical damage per basic attack, working of only getting 3 autos in 4 secs that's an extra 253.92 damage, in the same time grasp will only return 50hp-100hp if you fight ticks just over 4 secs for reset (given that you are at 2k hp at this stage). expand it out a lil bit, fight goes for 7 seconds you can apply 6-7 basic attacks 507-592 damage with fevor and for grasp you can only sustain max 100 hp at 2k hp

as you see, raw numbers stack in the favor for fevor. That's my take on the difference

Ah the numbers. Now we're analysing! 
At 8 stacks it does do a lot of damage yes, I can 100% agree with that, but firstly we have to get to 8 stacks right? 3 auto's to get 253.92 is after you've found a way to stack it in the first place, Grasp does become slightly more efficient by this stage with numbers also assuredly.

Remembering that Grasp of the Undying, whilst it's handy at dealing a bit of % damage, it also heals you to keep you alive, which would you value more on these champions? Damage or Sustain for the tanks?

firstly for a tank battle in extended lanes, fight will go for around 20 secs or more, 1 rotation of abilities and autos will give you full stacks and take roughly 2 secs with both champs leaving the remaining 18 secs full damage from fevor, so lets go with in that time frame 14 autos to be cautious cause we arent all pros :) 12 x 253.93 = 3047.16 bonus damage compared to a 21 sec fight for grasp @2000hp 2.5% is 50hp, can get a max of 5 times, thats only 250hp.

would you prefer 250hp for that fight or 3k of extra damage? with fevor, you either kill, force from lane and burn pots /summoners allowing for team plays around map

secondly, a team fight at same level these wont go for as long as your target should be dead. lets go with 10 secs to kill the carry, 4 sec to get full stack as you need to get to backline and an auto or 2, leaving 6 seconds on target get 4 autos. 4 x 253.93 = 1015.72 adc or mid out of fight then you turn onto other of the 2 carries, didnt really get efficient stacks cause was low hp, but consumed 4 more secs. time to kill support and top tanks 3 more secs to get fevor stacks since your in the fight, 5 autos and tank is dead fight over. that is roughly going to be how the team fight goes, give or take a lil.

analysis for that is total fight went for 22 second, only able to get 9 autos at full stacks during this fight 9 x 253.93 = 2285.37 bonus damage for the fight also allowing you to push the carries out of fight efficiently or kill. keeping your team protected from wipe, also extends fight to get team set up defensively with re spawns

same fight 22 secs 6 x 2.5% = 300hp regen. my point of view here is that 300 hp in a team fight might keep you alive for 2 more seconds, but the damage that you deal far outweighs the damage you can absorb.

Now that the numbers are out, tactics come into play as well. lets say because of that extra damage you do to kills adc but you die, your team now has 2 carries a jg and support, enemy team has 1 carry, 1 support, 1 tank top and jg, who is more likely to win this fight given your team now should do more damage?turns out enemy doesnt want to fight because its uneven fight, you can now pressure baron/dragon and force a fight, or push a tower freely because they cant defend it. So tactically there is alot more objectives you can control by trading your top for their carry
oh ill add, both these champs can get in and out of fights aswell, so going deep doesnt always mean death

Okay I'd like to give my reasoning as to why Fervor is better than Grasp for top Fizz and Ekko - and this comes down to inherently WHY top Fizz and Ekko are good in the first place; because of their ability to give out a lot of damage in extended trades. This is where the power lies in fervor and why it has an edge over grasp on both these top lane champions.

You can build better health tank items than damage tank items. Plus they need the dmg

Ekko and Fizz are mobile champions that excel in dueling. Grasp of the undying has its perks in laning and short fights, however with lane swaps occurring frequently grasp of the undying isn't helpful for the first 10 or so minutes. Fervor of battle on the other hand provides a good mixture of damage, kill potential, and the ability to win all ins. While grasp provides percentage damage and sustain alot of the top lane builds consist of a lot of resistances rather than health giving fervor even more of an advantage. Another reason which quite a few people forget about is the 'piercing thoughts' that provides 7% magic penetration mastery which counters the resistance stacked items the enemy top laner most likely will build, AP tanks struggle to kill tanks with magic resist as they dont have any magic penetration through their items. With all this information fervor of battle stands out as the obvious go to mastery for ekko/fizz top.
